title: Words and phrases defined
context: PART V. CHICKEN EGGS §147-71 Words and phrases defined. Whenever used in this part, unless the context otherwise requires: &ldquo;Addled&rdquo; or &ldquo;white rot&rdquo; means an egg which is putrid or rotten. &ldquo;Adherent yolk&rdquo; means an egg in which the yolk has settled to one side and become fastened to the shell. &ldquo;Black rot&rdquo; means an egg which has deteriorated to such an extent that the whole interior presents a blackened appearance before the candle. &ldquo;Blood ring&rdquo; means an egg which contains blood. &ldquo;Consumer&rdquo; means any person purchasing eggs for the person&rsquo;s own family use or consumption, or a restaurant, hotel, boarding house, bakery, or other institution purchasing eggs for serving to guests or patrons, or for its or their use in cooking or baking. &ldquo;Eggs&rdquo; means chicken eggs in the following forms: (1) Uncooked in the shell; and (2) Liquid, frozen, or dried whole egg meats, whites of eggs or egg yolks. &ldquo;Moldy&rdquo; means an egg in which mold has developed inside the shell. &ldquo;Retailer&rdquo; means any person, firm, corporation, or association which sells eggs to a consumer. [L 1931, c 70, §2; RL 1935, §1074; RL 1945, §1305; RL 1955, §22-70; am L 1959, c 5, §1(b); HRS §147-71; am L 1985, c 18, §1; gen ch 1985] Revision Note Definitions rearranged.
